“This bill gave the National Investigation Agency (NIA) exclusive powers. NIA may take any person in custody under UAPA without the prior authorization of the state government. This is against the federalism guaranteed by the Constitution of India.”

“The identification of organizations as terrorist organizations and the identification of individuals as terrorists are quite different. When a person is named as a terrorist, he will face social exclusion and be without a basis of existence, even if he has proved the opposite. The consequences will be irreversible. For example, in 2016, only 67% of cases ended up being released, which means they are likely to be innocent.”

“When someone is booked under UAPA, the burden to prove their innocence is on them. This new change will enable the government to capture its property. How will they then pay for legal expenses to prove their innocence if they are wrongly accused?”

This will provide more police to the central government. The provision to call individuals terrorists can be abused. For example, recently several civil activists are called Urban Naxals. If someone opposes the government, they will be vulnerable to being captured as terrorists. Because this change made it easier to describe someone as terrorists.”

“There is a growing threat of lonely wolf terrorism. Single wolf terrorists have no connection with terrorist organizations, but they carry out terrorist attacks alone. This new UAPA change has the potential to suppress single-wolf terrorism.”

“To prevent human rights violations, a four-step examination is added. The identification of individuals as terrorists is not begun in India. The United States, the European Union and China also have this provision.”

So far, only organizations have been referred to as terrorist organizations, but not as individuals. The hole in this are the individuals of the banned organizations that form new organizations and carry out terrorist activities. This amendment to the law on illegal activities (prevention) allows the government to describe individuals as terrorists, which can prevent terrorist attacks.”
In light of the increasing threat by terrorists, terrorism needs to be strictly combated. Therefore, a strengthening of the UAPA is necessary.

"Today, India has no well-built infrastructure to ensure data security. On the other hand, the industrial countries already have efficient infrastructure. So, if we rush towards data localization, this may not be a wise step. Without efficient infrastructure, data is vulnerable to cyber attacks. And the risk is great here because it is financial data. But how the laws are made, it’s a big challenge to develop efficient infrastructure at a faster pace.”

“The storage of data in India means higher operating costs for the operators of payment systems. In other countries, they have cheaper alternatives. And even in cross-border transactions, they need to store the data in two places, which increases the cost. It is likely that these additional costs will be transferred to the consumers.”

"Data localization laws lead to the construction of several data centers on the site. This will create a lot of jobs and greatly help the country’s economy. It will also promote innovation in this area that will lead to cost-effective solutions.”

“With the investigation of crimes it will be necessary to access the payment data. If the data is stored abroad, it is very difficult to obtain permission from that country for access to the data. This leads to delays in the resolution of crimes. If the data is stored here in our country, this problem will be avoided.”

India is a large consumer market for many foreign companies. India and other developing countries recognize the economic value of data and the importance of data localization. Data localization will benefit domestic companies and the country’s economy. And we can also ensure the security of the data.

“The data is considered a ‘new form of wealth’. Companies generally use data to understand consumer requirements and influence their behavior. New products can be developed by analysing the data to meet the needs of consumers. The data has an economic value. In general, the industrial countries take advantage of this opportunity with their well-developed infrastructure.”

“We are in a globalized world. Currently, the world runs on the free flow of people, goods, services and data. Data localization laws seem to be part of the protectionist policy, which is a threat to the free flow of data.”

“The United States is against data localization laws. Recently at the G20 summit, U.S. President Donald Trump spoke against data localization. His attitude is natural because it increases the operating costs of U.S. companies. The bilateral relations between India and the United States are important for both countries because we are in the export and import of IT services, professionals and goods, etc. They are flooded. So imposing data localization laws without threatening Indo-US relations is another challenge.”
“We can guarantee data protection by locating the data.”
Data localization can lead to a state monitoring of its citizens.
“Data localization is important for data sovereignty, which means that the data of citizens should belong to the respective governments and not to other countries.”

“The law is very clear that RTI is not only dealing with government agencies alone. It is also intended for non-governmental organizations that are essentially financed and controlled by the government. There are numerous subsidies (including tax exemptions) that political parties enjoy, thus they are essentially funded by the government.”
“Political parties are independent bodies, they do not have to be liable to the public. They were not made by the Constitution or an act of Parliament.”

“According to the RTI law, these organizations, where there is public interest, must be transparent and subject to the law. Today there are a number of private organizations, whether partially funded or fully; schools, hospitals, etc. that are under the RTI law and not just government organizations.”
“There are appropriate provisions in the Income Tax Act and with the Election Commission so that people can have all the information they want.”

The RTI Act contains provisions in Section 8, in which the concept of competitive interest is mentioned. Certain exceptions shall be granted in cases where it can be demonstrated that the dissemination of information may harm the competitive advantage of the party. This is a problem not only with the political parties, but also with many government and private bodies.”

It is believed that political financing is the source of corruption. Citizens have the right to know where the political parties get these funds, how they spend these funds and on the basis of their decisions. The Crony capitalism is enormously blocked when political parties are brought under the RTI Act.”

According to the IT law, political parties do not have to disclose donations they receive under INR 20,000. An informal study conducted in 2010 on 6 major political parties shows that they raised Rs 700 crore. 95% of the amount was raised by amounts below Rs 20,000. There is a great possibility that the political parties will take advantage of this gap.”
“Political parties express certain promises in their manifests. After the election, citizens have the right to know why the promises made by the political parties have not been fulfilled.”

“Political parties are of central importance for the functioning of democracy. Political parties continue to form the government. The government policy is then governed by the party ideology. This will make it essential for the political parties to fall under the field of the RTI.”

“If political parties fall under the RTI, this will affect their smooth internal functioning. Rivals can use RTI to offend each other. Since the political parties are not directly connected to the public, a RTI would be invalid.”

“In the whole, educational institutions are viewed as work machines, we expect to get unemployed and get out with work. We do not realize that we need to improve our skills to become worthy of employment. This is why more than 80% of engineers are unemployed and the figures for non-engineers are even worse.”

Although we have founded institutions at national level over the past 40 years, we have not invested in keeping their standards. Qualitative education requires funds. Even the Indian top institutions lack infrastructure, laboratories, resources, etc. And even what is available is only to keep the students in the exam and sit off the rest of the time.”
“Today, no problem has a single solution and no new technology is connected with a single discipline. We need several contributions from several disciplines, and our institutions have not done that.”

"Indian students provide brilliant achievements when they go to different countries in the field of research. This means we don’t lack talent, we lack infrastructure and a healthy environment for our sharp heads.”

“We have not paid our teachers at the level that their colleagues in other countries deserve. The result is that people hesitate on the idea of teaching as a career. We’ve also failed to attract successful foreign faculty to our institutions.”

“To excellence in everything takes time. Through the graduation, the students acquire so much knowledge in the relevant field. So it’s easier for employers to train these students for the industrial requirements.”
“Every skill can be learned and mastered, even if we don’t have a degree in it. Programming is no exception.”

"Even if someone has an IT degree, he has to learn so many things to get into the IT job because there is a gap between the industrial standards and the skills taught in engineering schools. Furthermore, as the technology is constantly developing, even if someone has prepared for industrial standards in his degree, they need to constantly learn new technologies to remain relevant on the labour market. So as the learning curve will also be there for IT students, students from non-IT backgrounds can also learn these things and enter IT jobs.”

“The number of IT jobs is growing rapidly due to the technological revolution. There will be more jobs in the IT sector. And if the recruits are very strictly above the degree, they may miss a large pool of talents that have a non-IT background. "

"Now we have so many online courses platforms through which we can learn almost every skill from experts. We can also receive certificates if we pass the tests. So, as Tim Cook said, a 4-year degree seems old and traditional. "

"In many of the Indian engineering colleges, we can easily transfer the subjects, even if we don't have much knowledge in these subjects. That’s why many companies are unable to find the right talents, even if there are so many qualified graduates. So the willingness to become experts in this field is more important than a degree. "
"If a student from non-IT background has decided to start a career in the IT field, the efforts they put in graduation will go out of mind."

Although the new programming languages replace the old, the basic concepts for almost all programming languages are the same. So whoever has a degree in coding has a advantage over the student from a non-IT background.”

“People change careers even after working in a field for several years because our interests change. So if someone can do this while he has so many personal duties, it’s much easier for young people to learn a new skill.”
“Variable salary definitely increases the productivity of employees. Strong people feel rewarded and rewarded for their efforts, while weak people feel motivated to improve.”

“In variable salary systems, employees feel satisfied and motivated with their work. They believe to be an active part of the organization, the organization recognizes it as part of its growth and appreciates its efforts.”
“Variable payments help inining valuable employees. This helps to keep good talents for a long time and thus fewer spending on setting new talents. This ensures stability for the organization.”

It has been found that it is difficult to keep workers in weak times when they are on variable wages systems. Workers who receive provisions do good when the business is good, but they do bad when the business is bad. In times of slow business, even top sellers may have difficulties in selling enough to earn a decent maintenance. If the market is slow and contractors can’t earn enough, they can look for other employment opportunities. In poor times, fixed wages can be more effective to prevent workers from using other options.”

Variable payments can lead to unhealthy competition between employees. They are less willing to help each other. Team cooperation can have a negative impact. In the long run, the relationships between colleagues can become bitter. While workers at fixed wage systems are able to maintain heartbreaking relationships at the office.”

“Most sales jobs have a variable component. This could have a negative impact on the employee’s attitude towards customers. You can force the customers irrationally to only make profits for themselves. You could exaggerate the price to the customers just to make more profits. While a worker with a fixed salary would maintain healthy and positive relationships with the customers, the right balance in their approach.”

“Our continent Europe is debtful and has no means to take care of people who have never paid taxes and continue to ignore our laws! We already have enough poor people in Europe, and we have to take care of them!”

“I do not agree to take people away their right to asylum and their right to live in the EU because they have come illegally. I would instead propose to facilitate legal migration. In this way there will be no need to illegally migrate and risk your lives.”
The departure of refugees is a long-debated plan. At the end, however, no participating group agreed to these plans. Some countries do not like these people at all.
